Class RautSoftChart

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          java.awt.Window
              java.awt.Frame
                  javax.swing.JFrame
                      RautSoft.plot.RautSoftChart
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer, javax.swing.WindowConstants
public class RautSoftChart
extends javax.swing.JFrame

RautSoft Plot package provides various charts and plotting methods. These are public static methods can be used from any programs.

Since:
1.0
Version:
1.0
Author:
Lakshmi K. Raut

Field Detail

N_POINTS

public static int N_POINTS
A public static integer determines at how many points the function to plotted. Higher number makes it smoother. Default is 100.

plotLegend

public static java.lang.String plotLegend
This is public static String field of the class. YOu can set it to the string that you like to have as a legend for the plot of your one variable function. 
 Example:
 
 plotLegend = "myf(x)";
 
 default is 
 plotLegend = "f(x)";

plotTitle

public static java.lang.String plotTitle
This is public static String field of the class. You can set it to the string that you like to have as a title of the plot of your one variable function. 
 Example:
 plotTitle = "my Plot of f(x)";
 default is 
  plotTitle = "Plot of f(x)";

plotXAxisLebel

public static java.lang.String plotXAxisLebel

public static java.lang.String plotYAxisLebel
Constructor Detail

RautSoftChart

Method Detail

plot

public static void plot(FunctionOfOneVariable f,
                        double x0,
                        double x1)
Main plot function. First create an instance of FunctionOfOneVariable function or a vector of such functions and then pass it through the method. The method is overloaded to take various one function or a vector of functions. Here are two examples: 
 Example 1:
 FunctionOfOneVariable f = new FunctionOfOneVariable() {
 public double value(double x){return x*x;} };
 plotLegend = "f(x)= x*x";
 plot(f , -100.0,100.0);
Example 2: 
FunctionOfOneVariable f1 = new FunctionOfOneVariable() {
             public double value(double x){return 10*Math.pow(x,0.2);} };
             
       FunctionOfOneVariable f2 = new FunctionOfOneVariable() {
             public double value(double x){return 10*Math.pow(x,0.5);} };
             
       FunctionOfOneVariable f3 = new FunctionOfOneVariable() {
             public double value(double x){return 10*Math.pow(x,0.7);} };
             
           
       FunctionOfOneVariable f4 = new FunctionOfOneVariable() {
             public double value(double x){return 2+Math.pow(x,0.7);} };
                  
             FunctionOfOneVariable [] ff = new FunctionOfOneVariable[4];
             ff[0] = f1;
             ff[1]=f2;
             ff[2] = f3; 
             ff[3]=f4;
             double [] x0 ={0,0,0,0};
             double [] x1 ={2.0,3.0,3.0,3.0};
             
             plot(ff,x0,x1);

Parameters:
x0 - Lower value of x to be plotted in the x-axis
x1 - Upper value of x to be plotted in the x-axis
f - Function of One Variable

plot

public static void plot(FunctionOfOneVariable[] f,
                        double[] x0,
                        double[] x1,
                        java.lang.String[] sn)
This is overloaded to take a vector of functions and lower and upper values for each function

Parameters:
sn - not used
x0 - A vector of doubles corresponding to the lower value of corresponding function
x1 - A vector of doubles corresponding to the upper value of corresponding function
f - A vector of FunctionOfOneVariable objects

plot

public static void plot(FunctionOfOneVariable[] f,
                        double[] x0,
                        double[] x1)
This is overloaded to use default legends for the plots of a a vector of functions and lower and upper values for each function

Parameters:
f - a vector of FunctionOfOneVariable objects
x0 - a vector of doubles corresponding to the lower value of corresponding function
x1 - a vector of doubles corresponding to the upper value of corresponding function
